text: today's kitchen conundrum we are
tackling the lighter and thinner version
of the American pancake and that is the
French crepes crepes are notoriously
difficult for people to make at home
they might get the consistency wrong or
they might not know how to make them in
the pan well today I'm going to show you
the very simple recipe in making crepes
and the technique behind it all so first
of all we need 2 cups of whole milk and
today I'm using a blender to mix my CREP
batter together you could certainly use
a bowl and a whisk I just think that a
blender really helps make a really nice
consistent batter to this I'm going to
add three whole eggs these are large
eggs at room temperature five
tablespoons of unsalted butter that I've
melted and have cooled you don't want
this to be too hot 1/2 teaspoon of
kosher salt and one in 3/4 cups of
all-purpose flour so very simple
ingredients ingredients that you
probably already have on hand filling up
my blender almost to the top but we'll
start on low speed cap this up and you
want to blend this until it's nice and
consistent it almost has the texture of
heavy cream so that'll take a few
minutes here in the blender
so that our batter looks great now just
to ensure that there are no lumps in the
batter I'm going to strain the CREP mix
through a fine mesh strainer there
shouldn't be any lumps but if there are
you can just push them through one trick
here is in letting your batter rest
overnight so I'm going to cover it with
plastic wrap this goes into the
refrigerator and this resting period
helps to develop the flavor in the CREP
batter and ultimately the end prep and
also it helps to relax the batter and it
yields a less tough crepe so the CREP
batter has been resting overnight you
can see the consistency it's nice and
thick and smooth that time in the
refrigerator overnight what it does is
there any air bubbles that accumulate in
the batter they slowly float up to the
top and dissipate so it makes an even
smoother batter I have an 8-inch
nonstick skillet heating over medium
heat and just lightly brush the pan with
a little bit of melted butter not too
much the more butter you add to the pan
the more of a pattern a brown speckled
appearance you'll get on your crepe and
to my CREP pan here I'm going to add
about two tablespoons of CREP batter
swirl the batter in the pan coming up
along the sides and you're going to cook
this until the edges start to lift up
from the sides of the pan and the edges
will start to turn a golden-brown color
now in Paris they have CREP carts all
over the city
with flat burners and you actually
spread the CREP batter on the pan and
they make these delicious wonderful
crepes this seems to be looking good has
a nice color a few minutes on each side
and then what you can do with crepes
which is really great as you can make
them in advance you can make them the
day before and put them into the
refrigerator before you're ready to
serve them with either a sweet or savory
filling or you can freeze crepes in
stacks as well you just want to make
sure that you defrost them thoroughly
before you try and separate them this
guy looks great here right onto the
stack gently slide your offset spatula
you can use a rubber scraper here just
using this to kind of peel up the side
of the CREP and then give it one flip
and there you go you have the recipe for
the CREP batter and with these expert
tips and tricks you will have success
with crepes every single time you make
them enjoy
you
